metadata.title: Densification improvement of spark plasma sintered TiB2-based composites with micron-, submicron- and nano-sized SiC particulates

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Ceramics International
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ceramint
Densification improvement of spark plasma sintered TiB2-based composites with micron-, submicron- and nano-sized SiC particulates
Zohre Ahmadia, Behzad Nayebib, Mehdi Shahedi Aslc,⁎, Iman Farahbakhshd, Zohre Balake
a Young Researchers and Elite Club, Miyaneh Branch, Islamic Azad University, Miyaneh, Iran bDepartment of Mining and Metallurgy Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic), Tehran, Iran c Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Mohaghegh Ardabili, Ardabil, Iran d Department of Mechanical Engineering, Quchan Branch, Islamic Azad University, Quchan, Iran e Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Ahvaz Branch, Islamic Azad University, Ahvaz, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Spark plasma sintering Densification TiB2 SiC Particle size
A B S T R A C T
Taguchi design of experiments methodology was used to determine the most influential spark plasma sintering (SPS) parameters on densification of TiB2–SiC ceramic composites. In this case, four processing factors (SPS temperature, soaking time, applied external pressure and SiC particle size) at three levels were examined in order to acquire the optimum conditions. The statistical analysis identified the sintering temperature as the most effective factor influencing the relative density of TiB2–SiC ceramics. A relative density of 99.5% was achieved at the optimal SPS conditions; i.e. temperature of 1800 °C, soaking time of 15min and pressure of 30MPa by adding 200-nm SiC particulates to the TiB2 matrix. The experimental measurements and predicted values for the relative density of composite fabricated at the optimum SPS conditions and reinforced with the proper SiC particle size were almost similar. The mechanisms of sintering and densification of spark plasma sintered TiB2–SiC composites were discussed in details.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Non-oxide structural ceramics are ideal candidates for high temperature applications due to their high strength and refractoriness. [1,2]. Titanium diboride (TiB2) is an important and well-known member of ceramic materials and an interesting candidate for many ultrahigh temperature structural applications including crucibles, cutting tool materials, corrosion and wear resistance parts as well as light weight armors for ballistic protection. High elastic modulus (529 GPa), exceptional hardness (~ 32 GPa) and good strength at room temperature are often reported for monolithic TiB2 and TiB2-based ceramics [3–8]. However, it is difficult to sinter and densify the TiB2 matrix composites by conventional manufacturing methods owing to covalent characteristic of their bonding and high melting point as well as their low bulk and grain boundary diffusion rates [9]. Therefore, extremely high temperatures (> 2000 °C) are generally needed for densification of TiB2 powder. However, such high sintering temperatures result in abnormal grain growth and consequent microcracking which can reduce the value of mechanical properties. In addition, if the grain size exceeds the critical value, the anisotropy of the hexagonal grain structure of TiB2 causes disadvantageous internal stresses and initiates self-acting microcracks during cooling stage. Moreover, the formation
of surface oxide impurities (TiO2 and B2O3 on the surface of TiB2 powder) has a destructive influence on the densification phenomenon. Using various metallic and non-metallic materials as sintering aids to fabricate dense TiB2-based composites is an appropriate way to overcome such problems [10–13].
The introduction of different non-metallic sintering additives such as B4C, TiC, SiC, Al2O3 and MoSi2, significantly improved the sinterability and mechanical properties of TiB2 ceramics and inhibited the grain growth [14–22]. It was found that SiC incorporation in the TiB2 parts modified their sinterability and densification behavior. During the sintering route, SiC eliminates the oxide impurities from the surface of powders via chemical reaction with TiO2 which minimizes the grain coarsening and forms a liquid phase grain boundary (amorphous SiO2). Hence, the microstructure evolution and densification enhancement by adding an appropriate amount of SiC are attributed to the liquid phase sintering (LPS) mechanism which results in a significant enhancement in the fracture toughness and strength as well as high temperature oxidation resistance [23–26]. Moreover, it was observed that the reaction between TiB2 and SiC leads to the formation of in-situ TiC as a new phase. This observation suggests that the extreme enhancement in densification and sinterability is due to the presence of TiC (4.93 g/ cm3) which forms during the sintering process [8,24,26].
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2018.03.202 Received 24 February 2018; Received in revised form 21 March 2018; Accepted 22 March 2018
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: shahedi@uma.ac.ir (M. Shahedi Asl).
Ceramics International 44 (2018) 11431–11437

sections.heading: Available online 23 March 2018
sections.text:
0272-8842/ © 2018 Elsevier Ltd and Techna Group S.r.l. All rights reserved.
T
Several techniques are widely used for densification of TiB2 ceramics and TiB2-based composites including pressureless sintering (PS), hot pressing (HP) and spark plasma sintering. Torizuka et al. [27–29] demonstrated that SiC plays an effective role in improving the sinterability of TiB2, but the detailed sintering mechanism was not clarified. TiB2–SiC composites with different amounts of SiC (1–10wt%) were sintered by hot isostatically pressing (HIP) at 1500–1900 °C and a relative density of 96% was obtained by adding 2.5 wt% SiC to TiB2 matrix. During the sintering process, SiC reacted with TiO2 and amorphous SiO2 as well as TiC were formed [30]. Alavi et al. [31] showed that relative density of TiB2-based ceramics sintered at 1800 °C, can reach 99% by adding 10wt% nano-sized SiC particles. The density enhancement was attributed to the chemical reaction between SiC and TiO2, formation of SiO2, and decreasing of porosities. Incorporation of more SiC up to 30wt%, led to the decrease in relative density due to the remaining unreacted SiC particles. Sabahi et al. [24] investigated the effects of SiC particles (0–30 vol%) on the microstructure and mechanical properties of hot pressed TiB2 at 1850 °C for 2 h under 20MPa pressure. A fully dense TiB2–30 vol% SiC was obtained due to the formation of in-situ TiC. They also investigated the hot pressed TiB2-based composites, reinforced with SiC whiskers (0–30 vol%), under the same processing conditions. Fully dense composites with 15 and 20 vol% SiC whiskers were achieved due to the elimination of oxide impurities [9].
In this paper, the influence of the sintering temperature, applied pressure, soaking time, and the size of the SiC particles on the densification behavior of the spark plasma sintered TiB2–SiC composites were studied. An optimization plan was used to find the optimal experimental conditions in order to reach the highest density. Taguchi design of experiments can be employed as a helpful method to overcome the confusing problems, because few tests are needed in this methodology. The evaluation of factors through few tests is possible by the design of experiments based on orthogonal arrays [32]. Previous studies have investigated the effects of processing parameters on the characteristics of ZrB2 [33–43] and HfB2-based composites [44] by the Taguchi method. To the best of our knowledge, there is no published paper focusing on the densification of TiB2-based materials regarding the Taguchi methodology. However, we have already published a supplementer for this paper which focused on the grain growth and hardness of these composites [45].

sections.heading: 2.1. Design of experiments
sections.text:
The Taguchi method engages the orthogonal arrays for the design of experiments to save the time and improve the data which can be extracted from the experimental results. This technique statistically determines the influence of various processing factors and identifies the functional correlations between the input and output parameters. Employing the statistical design of experiments helps foresee the optimal processing conditions in order to fabricate a product possessing the requested attributes [33,35,46]. Generally, there are three classifications for analyzing quality characteristic; the-lower-the-better, thehigher-the-better, and the-nominal-the-better [39].
In the present research, in order to obtain a high relative density, the-higher-the-better option is adopted. The Taguchi methodology uses the signal to noise ratio (S/N) for computing the deviation of the performance characteristics from the target values. S/N ratio displays the relation between the desirable (signal) and undesirable (noise) values for the output property. Taguchi method evaluates the effect of each parameter on the entire process and the contribution of parameters can be extracted by employing the ANOVA analysis [45,47]. In this work, the automatic design and statistical analysis of experiments were carried out using the Qualitek-4 software (developed by Nutek Inc., USA). The influence of SPS parameters (temperature, time, and pressure) as well as the size of the SiC particles were investigated. The selected
processing parameters at three levels are presented in Table 1. The number of such tests with full factorial design is 34 = 81. However, by using Taguchi method, only 9 experiments are needed based on the orthogonal array L9, as shown in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.2. Materials and process
sections.text:
Commercially available powders of TiB2 (micron-sized as the matrix phase) and SiC (micron-, submicron- and nano-sized particles as the reinforcement phases) were used as raw materials in the present work. The main characteristics of these starting materials are summarized in Table 3. A Teflon cup, ZrO2 balls, and ethanol were used as the ballmixing media. The submicron- and nano-sized SiC powders were initially dispersed in ethanol for 1 h in an ultrasonic bath, however the micron-sized SiC powder was directly incorporated in the TiB2 powder. The powder mixtures were adjusted to supply TiB2–20 vol% SiC composition for all samples.
The mixtures were ball-mixed at 90 rpm for 60min. Next, ethanol was evaporated on a rotary heater (HMS 14, Tebazma, Iran) at 90 °C. The dried powders were ground using an agate mortar and pestle, then sieved to produce uniform granules (100-mesh). Each powder mixture was placed inside a graphite die (inner diameter: 30mm), which was lined with a graphite foil. The sintering process was carried out using a spark plasma sintering apparatus (SPS-20T-10, China) at different temperatures (1600, 1700 or 1800 °C) under different pressures (10, 20 or 30MPa) for different soaking times (5, 10 or 15min) in vacuum, based on the Taguchi design (Table 2).

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterizations
sections.text: The phase analysis was performed by a Philips PW1800 X–ray diffractometer (XRD) using a Cu lamp (λ=1.54 Å). The bulk densities of the as-sintered composite samples were measured based on the Archimedes method with distilled water as the immersing medium. The relative density was estimated with respect to the theoretical value, calculated by the rule of mixtures. The microstructural characterization of the raw materials, the polished surfaces, and fractographs of the assintered ceramics were carried out using a Zeiss Sigma/VP field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM). The chemical analysis was simultaneously carried out using FE-SEM by a DXP–X10P energy dispersive spectroscope (EDS).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the SEM images of morphology of the as-received powders which qualitatively verifies the correctness of particle size of the raw materials. The results of relative density measurements, as a critical index of the progress of densification process in the as-sintered ceramics, are summarized in Table 4 and the variations with the processing factors are explained below.
Fig. 2 demonstrates the SEM micrographs of the polished surface and fractograph of sample 1, sintered at 1600 °C for 5min under a pressure of 10MPa with SiC particle size of 2 µm. As it can be clearly seen in Fig. 2a, the densification process has not progressed remarkably at such poor sintering conditions (e.g. at the lowest sintering temperature in this study). As it was reported in the literature [48,49], high sintering temperatures must be applied for densification due to the mainly covalent and ionic bonds of TiB2 as well as its low self-diffusion coefficients. Generally, temperatures over 70% of the melting point are needed during the sintering process in order to manufacture fully dense materials. Shahedi Asl et al. [50,51] suggested that the fragmentation and rearrangement of ZrB2 particles, with no considerable chemical bonding, are the main densification mechanisms in low-temperature sintering conditions. It seems that same mechanisms, i.e. fragmentation and rearrangement of particles, may have dominantly occurred in the case of TiB2-based composites. As it can be seen in Fig. 2b, there are many grains with particle size below 2 µm in the fracture surface, which are smaller than those of starting TiB2 and SiC powders (~ 2 µm). Based on this observation, the fragmentation of particles can be declared as
the dominant densification mechanism in sample 1. Fig. 3 presents the microstructure of fracture surface of sample 7,
sintered at 1800 °C for 5min under 30MPa with SiC particle size of 200 nm. As it can be clearly seen in this micrograph, neck formation between the adjacent particles is observable as a sign of improved sintering. Although the elimination of most of the cavities and porosities is a result of high atomic diffusion rate, few of them remained in the sample. The external pressure holds the grains together and makes fixed contact areas between them. Furthermore, it is possible to increase the contact area between the surfaces of particles by applying an external pressure which may help the plastic deformation. Several deformed TiB2 particles with flat polygon faces can be recognized in Fig. 3, marked by the arrows. The presence of dislocations was detected in pressureless sintered TiB2–SiC composite [52]. Hence, it seems that such linear defects can lead to the plastic deformation of TiB2 particles, assisted by the applied pressure in this work. Based on the relative density of sample 7 and according to the literature [8,24,26], adding nano-sized SiC particles and the in-situ formation of interfacial TiC phases in the TiB2 matrix composites facilitate the densification of material.
It was reported that the densification behavior of ZrB2–SiC composites improves using the smaller SiC particles [53,54]. It seems that such phenomenon generally happens in TiB2–SiC composites. Even though the SiC particle size in sample 8 (20 nm) is finer than that of sample 7 (200 nm), sample 7 with a relative density of 97.1% is denser than sample 8 with a relative density of 88.3%, as reported in Table 4. It may be due to the agglomeration of 20-nm silicon carbide particles and lower applied pressure of 10MPa, which leads to the fabrication of a low-density sample.
Fig. 4 demonstrates the SEM image of polished surface of sample 8. In addition to TiB2 and SiC, the presence of a new phase (TiC) is detected in this figure. Baik et al. [55] reported that there is an inherently narrow oxide layer (chiefly TiO2 and B2O3) on the surfaces of TiB2 which is formed during the powder making process, based on Eq. (1)
2TiB2 + 5O2 (g) = 2TiO2 + 2B2O3 (1)
TiO2 which is formed on the surface of TiB2 powder can react with SiC particles and result in the formation of TiC and liquid SiO2 phases after adding SiC to TiB2 (Eq. (2)). According to the SiO2-TiO2 phase diagram, a binary eutectic transformation occurs at 1550 °C [16]. The formation of liquid SiO2 leads to accelerated mass transfer which improves the sinterability and densification.

sections.heading: Sample Trial 1 Trial 2 Trial 3 Trial 4 Trial 5 Average S/N ratio
sections.text:
TiO2 + SiC = TiC + SiO2 (l) (2)
By increasing the sintering temperature, B2O3 melts at ~ 450 °C (Eq. (3)):
B2O3 (s) = B2O3 (l) (3)
During the sintering process, the reaction between SiC and oxide impurities (TiO2 and B2O3) leads to the formation of fine TiB2 particles along with CO and SiO gaseous products according to Eq. (4):
2TiO2 + 2B2O3 (l) + 5SiC = 2TiB2 + 5CO (g) + 5SiO (g) (4)
Elimination of the gaseous products from the samples immediately occurred because of the vacuum condition of SPS process. By increasing the temperature from 1400° to 1600°C, the residual volatile B2O3 evaporates and more TiO2 is produced. Consequently, SiC can react with the remaining TiO2 and form TiC phase, in accord with Eq. (5) [24].
2TiO2 + 3SiC = 2TiC + CO (g) + 3SiO (g) (5)
The diffraction peaks of initially added TiB2 and SiC and in-situ formed TiC phases are shown in the XRD pattern of as-sintered sample 9 (Fig. 5). Such observation is in agreement with the above-described reaction mechanism and SEM micrograph of Fig. 4. We have previously investigated the formation of TiC phase in the TiB2–SiC composites [9,24,26] as well as the formation of ZrC in the ZrB2–SiC ceramics doped with a ternary constituent such as short carbon fibers [39], graphene nano-platelets [56], graphite nano-flakes [57] and submicron-sized ZrO2 [34,40]. However, using other carbon sources such as B4C [58,59], carbon nanotube [60], carbon black [61] and nitride compounds such as SiAlON [62], AlN [63] and Si3N4 [64] did not result in the formation of ZrC phase in the ZrB2–SiC composites [36–38,65–67] or in ZrB2-based ceramics.
Fig. 6 demonstrates the plots of the main effects which show the variations in S/N ratios for relative density of TiB2–SiC composites regarding the processing parameters. These plots show an enhancement in relative density with all SPS parameters (temperature, time, and pressure). A decrease in SiC particle size, from 2000 to 200 nm, causes an increase in relative density. However, further decrease in SiC particle size, from 200 to 20 nm, results in lower relative density. A similar trend was reported for the effect of SiC particle size on the relative density of ZrB2-based ceramics fabricated by hot pressing [36]. The optimum processing conditions are identified from the peak points in
Table 5 ANOVA analysis explaining the significance of processing parameters on relative density.
Process parameters Degrees of freedom Sum of squares Variance Pure sum Significance (%)
SPS temperature 2 1.365 0.683 1.365 54.093 SPS soaking time 2 0.102 0.051 0.102 4.067 SPS pressure 2 0.586 0.293 0.586 23.224 SiC particle size 2 0.469 0.234 0.469 18.610 Total 8 2.523 – – 100.000
Fig. 7. Significance pie chart of processing parameters on relative density of TiB2–SiC composites.
these plots. This means that the highest relative density for TiB2-based composite which corresponds to the largest S/N ratios is achievable by SPS process at 1800 °C for 15min under 30MPa, reinforced with 20 vol % SiC with starting particle size of 200 nm.
ANOVA of the relative density is shown in Table 5, which identifies the sintering temperature as the main controlling and the most significant parameter on the densification of TiB2–SiC ceramics. Apart from the SPS temperature, the applied external pressure and SiC particle size are two other effective parameters on relative density. The SPS soaking time has the lowest importance on the densification progress of these composites. Fig. 7 demonstrates the pie chart of the significance of processing parameters on the relative density of TiB2–SiC composites. Based on Table 5, the contributions of SPS temperature, SPS pressure, SiC particle size and SPS soaking time on relative density are 54%, 23%, 19% and 4%, respectively.
The optimal manufacturing conditions and performance for the relative density of TiB2–20% SiC composites are given in Table 6. The highest relative density for TiB2-based ceramics is accessible at the optimum sintering conditions according to ANOVA; i.e. by SPS at 1800 °C for 15min under a pressure of 30MPa and the addition of 20 vol% SiC with particle size of 200 nm.
Based on the data in Table 4, the grand average of relative density in the current study is 86.9% and can be further increased by selecting the optimized processing variables. Based on the contributions of all parameters at the optimal processing conditions (Table 6), the relative density can reach 99.1%. This result indicates that fabricating a fully dense TiB2–SiC composite is possible. As an assessment, the confirmation test was used to evaluate the optimal conditions suggested by ANOVA. Therefore, five samples were sintered based on the suggested optimal processing conditions. The average relative density of the samples of confirmation test is 99.5% which is slightly more than the predicted value by ANOVA.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The effects of four manufacturing variables, i.e. the SPS temperature, the dwell time, the externally applied pressure, and the SiC particle size on the densification behavior of TiB2–20% SiC ceramics were studied using Taguchi methodology. The optimal manufacturing conditions, which help increase the relative density of TiB2 matrix composites, were determined. The statistical analysis identified the sintering temperature as the most important manufacturing parameter concerning the relative density. The contributions of sintering temperature, applied pressure, SiC particle size and soaking time were estimated 54%, 23%, 19%, and 4%, respectively. The experimentally measured relative density at the optimum manufacturing conditions (T= 1800 °C, t= 15min and P=30MPa) by adding optimum SiC particle size (200 nm) was 99.5%. According to the microstructural analysis, the in-situ formed interfacial TiC phases were detected at the TiB2/SiC grain boundaries. This phase was formed due to the chemical reaction between the SiC particles and the surface oxide impurities of TiB2 matrix, which consequently led to the relative density
enhancement.

metadata.abstractText: Taguchi design of experiments methodology was used to determine the most influential spark plasma sintering (SPS) parameters on densification of TiB2–SiC ceramic composites. In this case, four processing factors (SPS temperature, soaking time, applied external pressure and SiC particle size) at three levels were examined in order to acquire the optimum conditions. The statistical analysis identified the sintering temperature as the most effective factor influencing the relative density of TiB2–SiC ceramics. A relative density of 99.5% was achieved at the optimal SPS conditions; i.e. temperature of 1800 °C, soaking time of 15min and pressure of 30MPa by adding 200-nm SiC particulates to the TiB2 matrix. The experimental measurements and predicted values for the relative density of composite fabricated at the optimum SPS conditions and reinforced with the proper SiC particle size were almost similar. The mechanisms of sintering and densification of spark plasma sintered TiB2–SiC composites were discussed in details.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
